head.title: Report Warns About Cutting Remedial Aid

hedline.hl1: Report Warns About Cutting Remedial Aid

block.p: The elimination of remedial courses at colleges and universities by states facing budget constraints could block many poor and minority students from obtaining advanced training, a report by a higher education group reported today.

About 13 percent of undergraduates, or about 1.6 million students, took at least one remedial course in the 1992-93 school year, according to the report released today by the American Council on Education. The report said these students often came from lower-income families, were born outside the United States and did not speak English at home.

The elimination of remedial courses at colleges and universities by states facing budget constraints could block many poor and minority students from obtaining advanced training, a report by a higher education group reported today.

About 13 percent of undergraduates, or about 1.6 million students, took at least one remedial course in the 1992-93 school year, according to the report released today by the American Council on Education. The report said these students often came from lower-income families, were born outside the United States and did not speak English at home.
If you eliminate these courses, you are going to cut off their access to college," said David Merkowitz, a spokesman for the council.

Nineteen percent of black, Hispanic and Asian-American undergraduates and 15 percent of American Indian students took remedial courses in the 1992-93 school year, compared with 11 percent of white undergraduates, the report said.

Even though most institutions plan to continue offering remedial classes, educators in some states having difficulty balancing their budgets want to offer catch-up classes only at junior colleges, cut the number of remedial course offerings or limit them to first-year students.
Some states are tightening college admission requirements to lessen the need for remedial lessons, the report said. Others want high schools to pay for the remedial work for their graduates.

The City University of New York, tightened admissions requirements last year. Applicants judged unable to complete remedial courses within one year will be denied admission to four-year colleges and sent to community colleges, beginning this fall. The change will affect about 2,500 of the system's 213,000 students.

At Florida community colleges, nearly 70 percent of first-time students needed at least one remedial reading, writing or math class in the 1993-94 school year, said Linda Bradley-Long, a spokeswoman for the Florida House of Representatives' Committee on Higher Education. The courses cost the community colleges $53 million a year, she said.
Transferring the costs to high schools was discussed, but discarded, last year by Florida lawmakers. They decided instead to study ways to strengthen academic requirements in lower grades, she said.
